title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on lottery winnings or gambling payouts to pay child support arrearages. The distributor must suspend payment, withhold the arrearage amount, and pay it to the child support agency. The person making a payment under an insurance policy or settlement must suspend payment until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears. If arrears exist, they must withhold and pay the amount to the State agency. Additionally, payors in legal actions must also suspend payment until verifying arrears. When a payment is made under an insurance policy or settlement, it must be suspended until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears. If arrears exist, the amount must be withheld and paid to the State agency. In legal actions, payment must also be suspended until arrears are verified. When a payment is made under an insurance policy or settlement, it must be suspended until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears. If arrears exist, the amount must be withheld and paid to the State agency. In legal actions, payment must also be suspended until arrears are verified. Any person required to make payment in respect to a decedent shall suspend the payment until an inquiry is made to and a response received from the State agency as to whether the person otherwise entitled to the payment owes a child support arrearage. If there is an arrearage, the property may be sold, and the remaining proceeds or the amount of the arrearage will be paid directly to the State agency for distribution. When a payment is made under an insurance policy or settlement, it must be suspended until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears. If arrears exist, the amount must be withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants or delinquent child support payments until certain conditions are met. The State motor vehicle department may not issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations of noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. If an individual with a license or registration is found to have a warrant related to child support, they must prove why their license or registration should not be suspended until the warrant is resolved. The State may grant a temporary license or vehicle registration to individuals with outstanding child support warrants pending compliance with the order or warrant removal. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. If the seizure is not successfully challenged, the institution may pay the arrearage amount to the collecting entity. The amended Section 466(a) allows seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages, with the arrearage being the lesser of the amount owed or the amount in the account. SEC. 5. REPORTING OF CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS TO CREDIT BUREAUS. Amends Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act to require courts or agencies to report individual names and child support amounts to credit bureaus. SEC. 6. LIABILITY OF GRANDPARENTS FOR FINANCIAL SUPPORT OF THEIR GRANDCHILDREN. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. Amends Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
